title: CFMEU backdoor to work sites closed
text:
The Australian Building and Construction Commission argued that permits were required as even under the state legislation the officials were still exercising a right to enter work sites.

Justice Collier upheld the ABCC's interpretation.

“As a general principle, I agree with the Commissioner that it would be a nonsense to accept the argument advanced by the [CFMEU officials] (and the Minister) that, in so attending, the [CFMEU officials] had proceeded on the assumption that s 81(3) conferred no right of entry on anyone (including them), and was completely unenforceable by anyone," she said.

"Indeed, the fact that all individual respondents refused to leave the site despite being asked by representatives of the joint venturers to do so indicates that the individual respondents believed that they had exercised a right to enter the site in accordance with the WHS Act."

The ABCC's case concerned CFMEU officials unlawfully entering the $812 million Bruce Highway upgrade site in 2018 and causing work delays and requiring Queensland Police to attend.

CFMEU officials entered the project site on nine separate occasions, each time refusing to show their federal right of entry permits, and referring to rights under state workpace safety law.

While the court handed down temporary injunctions in April 2018 that prevented the officials from entering the sites without a permit, the CFMEU is understood to have continued to access other sites without permits and with the support of the state safety regulator.

A CFMEU spokesman said the union was considering the decision but would likely appeal.

Advertisement

The case will affect half a dozen Queensland officials who do not have entry permits, including state branch deputy and national president Jade Ingham.

Industrial Relations Minister Grace Grace said "the Palaszczuk Government intervened in the proceedings as it raised questions of law regarding the application of Queensland’s Work Health and Safety Act 2011".

"Our government respects the independence of the judiciary. We are currently analysing today’s decision."

The Federal Court will list the matter for a penalty hearing at a later date.
description: The Federal Court has dealt a blow to the Palaszczuk government by declaring its support for the CFMEU to enter worksites without a permit a legal "nonsense".
